conclusion: Understanding the relationship between the light source, objects, and their shadows is necessary.
The light source is positioned below the objects.
Objects (apple, paper, glass, and chicken leg) cast shadows (A, B, C, and D) on the ground directly beneath them.
When the light source moves upward, it will be positioned higher relative to the objects.
As the light source gets higher, the angle of incidence of the light rays will decrease.
The shadow of an object will move closer to the object as the light source moves upward.
Shadows A, B, C, and D will move closer to their respective objects.
The size of the shadow is determined by the angle of the light rays and the distance from the light source to the object.
As the light source moves upward, the angle of the light rays decreases, making the shadows smaller.
The shadows will become shorter and more compact.
Final answer: Shadows A, B, C, and D will move closer to their respective objects and become smaller.
